Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Federal Policy, Local Dynamics, and National School Lunch Programs

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
Skyrocketing childhood obesity rates in the United States have helped fuel mounting public concern about the health and well being of America's children. Efforts to address childhood obesity have increasingly targeted improvements to federal school food programs that provide critical nutrition to hundreds of thousands of children, including many low-income, minority youth who have been disproportionately affected by obesity. In particular, the landmark 2010 Healthy, Hunger-Free Kids Act (HHFKA) marked the first substantial changes to federal school food policy in recent years, and a growing grassroots farm-to-school movement has taken hold in cafeterias throughout the country. While previous research has traced the rich and often controversial history and development of the nation's school food programs, the time is ripe for in-depth analysis of school food politics in the aftermath of the groundbreaking changes to federal policy and increasing local school food reform activism. To this end, this dissertation explores the varying impact of the 2010 HHFKA on local school food landscapes and the complex realities of how select school districts are negotiating the terrain of school food politics in light of childhood obesity concerns. In doing so, this research contributes to our understanding of how federal policy affects school food politics on a local level, and how these dynamics affect subsequent actions and outcomes in the battle against childhood obesity.

Scholars of policy processes argue that federal policies, like the HHFKA, can have lasting top-down impacts on a variety of social and political dynamics. This literature, however, tends to neglect the role of state and local actors in the implementation of federal policies, and the role of bottom-up grassroots social change efforts on policy outcomes. Through a mixed methods design, this dissertation fills this lacuna in the literature by 1) quantitatively examining how school food programs across the country vary in nature as a result of differing local contexts in the aftermath of the 2010 federal legislation, and 2) qualitatively exploring the 2010 policy impact on the local landscape of school food politics through case studies of three California school districts. Drawing on analyses of national school food data, and fieldwork consisting of interviews, observations, and archival document research, this research provides an unprecedented opportunity to expand our knowledge of contemporary school food dynamics and to contribute comprehensive scientific information to critical policy discussions surrounding childhood health and nutrition.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Helena Lyson completed research for her dissertation “Exploring School Food Politics in the U.S. through a Mixed Methods Analysis of National Policy and Local Dynamics” supported by the NSF Doctoral Dissertation Research Improvement Grant. During her funding period, she completed quantitative analysis of national farm to school data and conducted qualitative fieldwork in two case study school districts in California including 65 interviews with key school food stakeholders, participant observation at 14 school food-related district meetings, site visits to 12 school cafeterias and kitchens, and archival document research of school district documents such as board of education meeting minutes, official reports, press releases, and media coverage. She was focused on exploring the varying nature, quality and implementation of federal school meal programs on both a national and local level in the aftermath of the landmark 2010 Healthy, Hunger-Free Kids Act in an effort to expand our knowledge of school food programs and to contribute comprehensive scientific information to critical policy discussions surrounding childhood health and nutrition.

 

Findings from her quantitative analysis indicate that state-level rates of farm to school programs, which can help increase student access to and consumption of fresh fruits and vegetables, vary significantly—with state affluence and the average farm to school rate of a state’s regional peers emerging as the most significant, positive predictors of farm to school rates. The quantitative findings shed important light on the impact of the interplay between federal school food policy and state-level factors on the presence of farm to school programs that can help schools provide the healthiest food possible to millions of students across the country every day. Importantly, the research illuminates concrete steps forward for facilitating more equitable school nutrition environments around the country including the need for increased federal grant funding to states with less internal wealth to subsidize the cost of pursuing farm to school programs. The research findings also suggest that advocating for state-level farm to school legislation, and increasing the number of food hubs that help build infrastructure for local and regional food systems throughout the country will also help to generate higher farm to school rates in states where accessibility to fresh and healthy food is needed the most. Lyson is awaiting a final publication decision from the peer-reviewed journal Food Policy after receiving an invitation to revise and resubmit a manuscript based on this quantitative analysis.

 

Preliminary findings from the qualitative research in the case study school districts indicate that school food program quality can vary significantly depending on local-level implementation practices. Research findings indicate that varying operational structures of federal school food programs play a significant role in setting local-level priorities for the meal programs on the ground. Findings from the case study district whose school food program is operated by an external food service management company, for instance, suggest that the program’s main focus is on financial stability, and that the program has been locked into the management company’s profit-driven structure.
